g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Successful mitigation must work in tandem with fundamental development goals such as access to
modern forms of energy. In many developing countries, access to electricity, clea
modern and efficient energy remain an essential societal priority. This is particularly true in sub
Africa and several Asian countries. SDG7 on universal access to modern energy includes targets on
able energy, and energy efficiency, which implies a profound
transformation of the current energy systems. Although there are different definitions of energy access,
the ultimate goal is universal access to clean and modern fuels.
Despite progress in some countries such as India, Bangladesh and Kenya, 860 million people were
without access to electricity in 2018, compared with 1.2 billion in 2010. About 2.65 billio
were cooking with solid fuels, distributed across Asia and Africa
Saharan Africa relied on traditional biomass (firewood and charcoal) for cooking, and 60
lied on kerosene and coal to meet their energy needs
responsible for 1.1 million deaths across Africa in 2019
2.2 billion people will still be dependent on inefficient and polluting energy sources for cooking by
Saharan Africa, and 650 million people are likely to rem
access to electricity in 2030, 90% of whom will reside in Sub
Research indicates that decentralised and on
grid renewables are likely the least cost options to provide
). Natural gas, LPG, and improved biomass
cookstoves are the most important options for cooking. Universal access to electricity and clean cooking
requires a rapid shift from traditional biomass to clea
ner fuels and/or clean cooking technologies
. It has been estimated that the provision of electricity and clean cooking for all would require
USD 786 billion in cumulative investment to 2030, equal to 3.4% of tota
Even without universal access to modern energy, increase
d access will substantially affect energy
systems through the deployment of renewable energy, LPG, and
biomass supply chains. Universal access for households, however, will have a minimal impact on global
has been estimated that universal access for household will increase energy demand
) relative to a future without any change in access to modern energy
coal but only modest declines in use
